name: bass-drum
definition: A large drum having a cylindrical body and two heads and producing a low, resonant sound.
description:
A bass drum is a large drum that produces a note of low pitch. It is typically cylindrical with the drum's diameter much greater than its depth.

Bass drums are made with a shell that is usually made of a type of wood (sometimes metal), with two heads (the part struck by the mallet or bass pedal) stretched over the two open shell ends.

The mallets used for playing the bass drum (when not using a bass pedal) usually have a thick handle often made of beech wood or hornbeam. The head usually has a wood core and is wrapped in felt material.

When a bass drum is part of a drum kit it is placed on the floor on feet, and the drummer hits the head with a bass pedal. Cloths are often used inside the head to dampen the sound.

The sounds produced by the bass drum have been described as thunderous, rumbling, pounding, hollow, mighty, and even soft at times.

Bass drum usage varies from keeping tempo in marches to rock and roll back beats to melodic voice in conjunction with the other parts of the set in jazz and classic music.

facts.name: Bass drum predecessors were used in wars
facts.value: Because of this unique tone, early bass drum predecessors were used extensively in war and combat, where a deep and percussive sound was needed to ensure that the forces were marching in proper step with one another.

facts.name: When is part of a kit bass drum may be used as support
facts.value: When the bass drum is part of a kit there are often other instruments mounted to the shell including the cowbell, and the kit also includes tom-toms, cymbals, snare drums, high hats, and others.

facts.name: The inventor of the bass pedal was William F. Ludwig
facts.value: The inventor of striking the bass drum with a bass pedal was William F. Ludwig, in 1909, in Chicago, Illinois.

facts.name: Famous drummers
facts.value: Some of the most famous drummers include Neil Peart (from the band RUSH), Buddy Rich, Ringo Star, Phil Collins, Benny Goodman, and Rick Allen (One-armed drummer for the band Def Leppard).

facts.name: In the orchestra setting the bass drum is suspended in a frame
facts.value: In the orchestra setting the bass drum is suspended in a frame that allows the drummer to change its position or angle. It is usually suspended by rubber straps or leather straps or wires.

facts.name: Bass pedal allows the drummer to play other instruments
facts.value: Adding the bass pedal to the drum kit made it possible for the drummer to play other percussion instruments such as snare drums, as well as cymbals, because their hands were free to use smaller drum sticks.

facts.name: The bass drum may be  part of a drum kit
facts.value: The bass drum as part of a drum kit (used in bands along with several other drums) was added in the beginning of the 1900s as part of jazz music.

facts.name: Various other sticks are used for the bass drum
facts.value: Various other sticks are used for the bass drum including hard felt sticks, leather sticks, wood sticks, side drum sticks, and brushes.

facts.name: Occasionally a timpani mallet is used for the bass drum
facts.value: Occasionally a timpani mallet is used for the bass drum when lower dynamic sounds are desired.

facts.name: Most bass drums are stationary
facts.value: Most bass drums are stationary, as in the drum kit set up. However when bass drums are used in marching bands they must be moveable and are suspended by straps or other apparatus to enable to drummer to walk with the instrument.

related.definition: A drum kit is a collection of drums and other percussion instruments set up to be played by a single player.
